top_comment.text: no wonder i fall on he ground every time i go to the restroom﻿
top_comment.author: huy luu

comments.text: why they always on the way... literally....
comments.author: tdeefox

comments.text: today i tripped when i got home from school...
comments.author: huy luu

comments.text: I do not even make it that far.  I trip at my bedroom door.
comments.author: jjjj

top_comment.text:
Hi Jackson! What about loud cats? I have a 14 year old female siamese that 
won't stop meowing from the time I get home to when I go to sleep. She has 
always been loud but it got much worse since my other cat died a couple 
months ago (her mother by the way).﻿
top_comment.author: Kristina Sala

comments.text:
She misses her mommy. She's also used to having a companion. Either give 
her lots more attention, or get a companion for her. To introduce them, 
watch the videos by Cole the Black Cat ("When Cole Met Marmalade" and "How 
To Introduce 2 Cats") and follow the advice in those. They are spot-on.
comments.author: Shalryn M.

comments.text:
Could she be full of energy now that her playmate is gone? Try playing with 
her in the evening to tucker her out, then feeding her, then bed time. 
Maybe she'll sleep instead of keeping you up.
comments.author: Melanie Pratt

top_comment.text:
I feel kind of bad for watching these videos without having a cat... my 
parents won't get a new one after our first was put down ,_,﻿
top_comment.author: Cyborg Rox

comments.text:
It's really hard when you lose a pet. It took 4 years for my family to be 
ready to have another cat after our first one died. Working at shelters is 
incredibly rewarding and very admirable but remember you gotta give people 
time to move on. :) Good luck!
comments.author: Claude VL

comments.text:
+Cyborg Rox
Yes there are actually quite a few animal shelters in Norway:
http://www.dyrebeskyttelsen.no/lokalavdelinger

If tere's no shelter near you, I'm sure somebody in your town/village would 
appreciate some help looking after their cats now and then :)
comments.author: Mettz

comments.text: I'm afraid there's not a lot of animal shelters in Norway
comments.author: Cyborg Rox

comments.text:
I'm so sorry for this situation, Cy. On the bright side, eventually you 
will be old enough to make your own decision about having a cat. In the 
meantime, perhaps you could volunteer at a shelter if there is one 
available. Your parents may become more impressed with your drive to love 
cats. You will also have a great opportunity to work with a lot of cats who 
need love and attention.
comments.author: MB Jones

top_comment.text:
I have a small problem with my cat when we are going to the vet. She tends 
to go under the seats, which I assumes she's afraid. She is 10 years old 
and just recently been introduce to riding a car. Whenever we are going to 
the vets nowadays I'll place a bag in front of the holes so that she can 
not enter. And also gives her treat when we come home again. Am I on the 
right path and is there anything more I can do to make her comfortable with 
the car ride? My other cat which has been introduced to car since he was a 
kitten is doing just fine. When we're driving to the vets he just sits in 
the armchair or at the back where he can see out. ﻿
top_comment.author: May Madsen

comments.text:
Well that's how we got her to the vets at first, in a crate. With blankets 
over it, she then starts to claw the walls of the crate and absolutely 
hating it now. That's why she is "loose" in the car, like the other cat we 
have. Before she get's out of the car to go to the vets office. Thats when 
I put a leash on her, but most of the time. I carry her, the vet we're 
taking her to is not crowed so. What we are doing now is blocking the back 
of the seat so she can't access underneath the seat. Now she just stays 
there, still not liking it. But she is doing better :) Crate is a safe 
place for cats who are used to it. So is car, not like it's a safe place 
for a cat. But they know the do's and don't if they're used to it. Thanks 
for the reply
comments.author: May Madsen

comments.text:
And you don't put her in a kitty crate to go to the vet, why? A crate is 
like their personal cave where they can feel safe and protected when going 
somewhere unfamiliar. And it keeps your cat out from under the brake pedal, 
which could be a bad thing when you have to stop.  Protect your cat in a 
crate while driving and when you get to the vet, they'll thank you for it. 
They usually request that your cat be contained in a crate for its own 
safety--no telling what dog, even on a leash in the waiting room, might 
want to lunge at your unprotected cat on your lap, and chasing your cat 
around the vet's office should it bail on you is not a really socially 
acceptable OR safe thing (for your cat) to do.
comments.author: Fisher Queen

comments.text:
Thank you I'll definitely give it a try, though she hates the car now xD 
However when the engine is off she is totally fine with it.
comments.author: May Madsen

comments.text:
i'd like to share my experience hope it'll help u in a way. at first i put 
my cat in a basket. let him be comfortable riding a car which does not 
always go to the vet like an evening drive or something. then i let him sit 
on my lap. later he'd go to top of the console and sit like a gps there. 
now he loves car ride :)
comments.author: Ant S

top_comment.text:
Three questions...1.) why does my cat choose to sleep between my legs at 
night when I'm sleeping? Sometimes it's ok, but it get's uncomfortable. 
When I move my cat, he get's up & then suddenly takes off out the room like 
something spooked him. 2.) how do i train my cat to use the leash? The 
harness is fine, leash, big issue. 3.) why doesn't my cat jump up on my lap 
like most cats do? I've had him for 2 years, so he's 2 years old, & not 
once has he come to me or jumped on the couch to sit with me, I'm puzzled. 
Thank you jackson. ﻿
top_comment.author: Chazz Kustomz

comments.text:
My Maine Coon has never been a lap cat. She will sit next to us on the 
couch (if her favorite spot is open) or on the arm rest (if it isn't, or if 
she just wants a higher perch). She is still very affectionate when we give 
her attention; she just wants her own spot like any person!
comments.author: Sayeth Di Puppeth

comments.text:
For the cat-leg-sleeper, it is just because we are their families. It is 
summer now and we have been suffering from 45°C (Buenos Aires, Argentina). 
Even during night, when temperature would be lower than 36°C, they were 
hugging me very tight (nope, we just have an old fan, not air 
conditioning). If it were just one cat, but being surrounded by 6 
hot-cats....
They may love being between the legs or arm-body. I even have 2 hugging to 
my head. Another one loves to lay over my chest. (diagram uploaded in 
GatisFelices blog a time ago).
They weight from 7 to 9 kilos each!

Lap-cats: give him some time. Some are very naughty and jump on top of me 
no matter what I am doing. And so, I have my back scratched and wounded... 
Or arms as I try to catch them in the air (almost flying cat).
Though not all cats love laying on you lap, they may love being by your 
side, almost hugging you.
It may be some confidence still missing. But same as people, we do not 
behave the very same way as other people do. Fortunatelly!!! You can have 2 
cats then. Twice the fun. Twice the love, though they may be different.
comments.author: Gatis Felices

comments.text:
I'm sure Jackson will have his own input; but I'll share from my experience 
on a couple of these questions - the sleeping between the legs I think is 
warmth and maybe security like when they would sleep with their litter 
mates - I notice in the summer they don't do it as much though. I have 
multiple cats and only a couple of them are lap cats - but again do it less 
in the summer and more in the winter. A couple won't sit on a lap but will 
snuggle and others just want to be petted and have their neck scratched, 
but won't lay down next to me; it's sort of a cat personality thing.
comments.author: LadyandHerCrazyCats

top_comment.text:
Great video! Question, Why does my 1 year old british blue cross " Mischa " 
drink from the tap? Is she lacking some vitamin/ mineral? and could she 
contract something bad from doing this? xxx﻿
top_comment.author: Louise trill

comments.text:
You could also fill a cup with a bleach-solution (or vinegar solution if 
you dislike bleach), hold it over the tap for a while, then rinse it off 
and run the water for a minute or two. That should make it nice and clean.
comments.author: Melanie Pratt

comments.text:
Nope, it's the water. My cat does that if given water from the tap. 
It's/how/ she's drinking, not why. If you want, try using an old toothbrush 
to try to get it clean, or just get her a cat fountain. I don't think 
they're very expensive.
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
+Melanie Pratt The only reason i asked about if its safe is because she 
actually sucks and puts her tongue up the tap itself. My bathroom is very 
clean but i cant clean inside the taps. Do you think its the taste of the 
metal perhaps that she likes?
comments.author: Louise trill

comments.text:
Still water in the wild is far more likely to harbor bacteria & bad algae. 
Running water is much safer to drink.
Cats aren't the only animals to do this - many of my reptiles will only 
drink running or rain water. It seems to be a survival-behavior.
comments.author: Melanie Pratt

comments.text:
This is very true. My cat enjoys her flowing water fountain.  Think of it 
this way: is it more fun to drink out of a cup, or out of a curly straw?  
It's a different way of drinking water, and my cat is hooked on flowing 
water. But Melanie is right; if the water out of the tap isn't safe to 
drink, the behavior needs to be stopped or a cat fountain needs to be 
bought.
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
Many cats prefer moving water. It's such a common thing with cats that 
there are cat-waterers that keep water moving available in stores.

Do you live somewhere where the tap water isn't safe to drink? If not, then 
it's all good.
comments.author: Melanie Pratt

comments.text: I second this question.  What do you think Jackson?

comments.text:
Frenzal does this if I've been away for a few days. It's a security thing, 
although in my case she doesn't get under my feet and in the way, just

I guess lots of attention might help?
comments.author: Claude VL

comments.text:
You're his safety net and companion. He trusts you to protect him. You 
might want to make a cat tree combined with a toy-station so he has toys at 
the ready as well as a great place to flake out and/or watch his territory. 
My cat started doing this after she lost her aunt and her dog in a short 
period. Now I'm her bodyguard. Color me flattered. :)
comments.author: Shalryn M.

comments.text:
I don't know, but I'd like to...My one cat wants to be in the same room 
with me as much as possible.  He'll pull open doors to get in the same 
room, he'll yowl if he can't be in the same room with me, and he hangs out 
as close to me as possible even in the room.  I call him my computer cat, 
because he's either next to my computer on his cat tree, or under the desk 
by my feet.
comments.author: Elaine Maze

comments.text: My cat did that when I first got him. Outgrew it pretty quickly.
comments.author: shcmoly

top_comment.text:
Please can you show us how to make some great cat toys because i can't get 
the toys you are using..﻿
top_comment.author: Josefsson9013

comments.text:
My cat's favorite toy is one of the toys that you can get at the dollar 
store for a dollar. It is the kind of toy that is attached to a stick by 
string. I love it because it is so easy to control the toy and make it act 
like prey while still keeping my hand away from his sharp teeth and claws
comments.author: Geeky Gal

comments.text:
All you really need is a piece of string with a pice of paper tied to one 
end. You can elaborate with feathers instead of paper, a rubber band 
instead of string and a wooden/plastic stick if you want. I promise you 
your cat will love it :) the cheaper, easier and simpler, the better :) And 
they'll let you know their favourites too. Oh, and give here/him empty 
cardboard boxes. You've seen the commercials with kids playing with the 
boxes, rather thant the toys that came in them? cats are the same :D
comments.author: Mettz

comments.text: Cabbage.
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text: The internet???
comments.author: Willeke Meers

comments.text:
Go outside and find a thin stick as long as your arm. Cut a length of 
string the same length as the stick. Tie the string to the thin end of the 
stick. Take two inches of soda straw and make a hole through the side at 
one end, about 1/4 of an inch away from the end, all the way through. Tie 
the loose end of the string through the holes you made in the straw. Take 
two wing feathers from a chicken, crow, or similar sized bird. The feathers 
should be from the same wing, or they won't spin as well. Dribble a little 
hot melt glue into the open end of the straw. Cram the feathers into the 
straw, back to back, so they spread out from the straw and form a sort of a 
V shape. Presto! A Cat Toy you has made! Take it and go play with your cat 
RIGHT MEOW.
comments.author: Sun Dog

top_comment.text:
Jackson, can a cat be a bit of both a tree and bush dweller? Delilah likes 
to be up on stuff but she also loves to be on the floor in the middle of 
everything. She's definetely not a hider. She's very confident.﻿
top_comment.author: Darci Stewart

comments.text: +Michelle Knowles LOL! Thanks for answering my question :D
comments.author: Darci Stewart

comments.text:
Of course I'm not Jackson, but, going by my own cat, I'd say yes. Dublin 
loves being up high, but he also likes to be in the middle of the floor, 
right where I walk. haha
comments.author: Michelle Knowles

top_comment.text:
Great video Jackson! We're really trying to figure this out about our two 
cats who don't like each other. We're moving into a new house and we want 
everyone to at least tolerate each other and enjoy their new home. Great 
explanations of the different types of dwellers. I'd like to see more 
information on how to help a hider feel confident when they share a house 
with another cat who tends to be a bully. Thanks.﻿
top_comment.author: Winnie Anderson

comments.text:
you need to play with the timid cat more, make it confident get toys that 
are like a feather on fishing line that make them jump and pounce do it 
everyday! you will notice a change i promise you. also feed the timid cat 
on the counter and your bully cat on the ground this in the cat world 
speaks volumes.. hope these tips help
comments.author: Hannah Walsh

comments.text:
I'm in nearly the exactly same situation so I would appreciate tips about 
this as well!
comments.author: Maya Sellon

top_comment.text:
How can I get two cats to become friends...cause every time they see each 
other, the older one runs up the stairs to my parents bedroom to hide. But 
I think that the younger one wants to play with the older cat ﻿
top_comment.author: olivia jarrett

comments.text: Thanks... That might work. And hopefully it does
comments.author: olivia jarrett

comments.text:
try the positive re-enforcement trick, feed the cats with the door closed 
with either cat on opposite sides of the door, they will smell each other 
but also smell food which is a positive, and every few days open the door 
more and more untill after two weeks or so the door can be open and they 
eat next to each other. it is a slow process so be patient but this works 
well. also try playing with the cats with an interactive toy so they can be 
distracted by something.. ps get like 2-3 litter boxes because they need 
there own pee and poo space hope this helps :)
comments.author: Hannah Walsh

top_comment.text:
Jackson, I need your help! When I was 12, I wanted to teach my second cat 
(first died at age two from cancer in a kidney, day before his 3rd b-day) 
to walk on a harness, but my parents wouldn't let me.  I am 22 now and wish 
to teach my new kitten to walk on a harness, but my mother is very against 
it.  She claims that he will learn that it can go outside and will be more 
likely to try to get out. She says "Indoor cats should be totally 
indoors."  I have seen your TV show My Cat From Hell, and have seen you 
tell some owners to take their cats out on harnesses. Please reply or email 
me at kukuibuss@gmail.com. I'll also try different ways to contact you on 
this question.  Thank you! =^..^=﻿
top_comment.author: kukui buss

comments.text: Thanks! That's great advice!
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
+LadyandHerCrazyCats Cats learn that outside time is always preceded with 
the ritual of the wearing of the collar/harness. Any other attempt to cross 
that threshold is met with a firm 'no', and maybe a reinforcing gesture (I 
use my foot held to block, and to push them back if necessary).
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text:
+kukui buss
It's kinda complicated, and is different for every cat. Prerequisite task 
is teaching the cat what 'No' means. (Another useful command is 'Be 
Careful'. That will help your cat navigate, say, a desktop without walking 
on your keyboard, or a shelf without knocking things off.)

When you start to open the door, the cat will charge towards the widening 
gap.  You open the door wide enough for her to see out, but not get out. 
You put your hand (or foot) in front of her face and tell her no. The 
moment she stops trying to get past, give praise! It's a good sign if the 
cat looks at you to try to understand what you're thinking. It means she's 
learning and listening. Always acknowledge her when she looks at you, when 
you are teaching her things, by nodding and blinking. She is saying, "I am 
listening to you." and you are saying back, "You are a good listener!"

Something to keep in mind is a narrow opening is more tempting to a cat 
than a wide open door. When you swing the door wide, the cat should keep a 
respectful distance, only looking curiously outside.
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text:
+Sun Dog Yeah, I have a harness made for a cat, but the figure eight sounds 
great for back up! Could you tell me how you teach your cats door manners? 
=^..^=
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
+kukui buss
Oh dear, don't teach dogs to chase cats! Cats have it hard enough as it is! 
Maybe better not to try walking your cat in your yard.

I don't know if Jackson covers door manners or not. Not that I've seen. I 
think he should, if he hasn't yet, but it may not be his style.

For a cat harness, use a figure eight style. (Do an image search on Google 
to see what it looks like.) You can make one easily with a soft strap or 
string, or yarn if the kitten is small enough not to break it. Make a loop 
that goes from around the neck, across the shoulders, under the belly, and 
back to the shoulders. Attach the leash where they cross like an X at the 
shoulders, and that's a figure eight harness.
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text:
+Sun Dog Door manners... does Jackson cover that in one of his YouTube 
videos, or would I have to look back at him teaching other cats in his TV 
series? And she's mostly worried of the kitten getting out of the harness. 
He did once already. My dad encourages our dog to chase cats out of his 
yard (cause the cats are so fast he knows the dog has no chance) and I 
forgot this when he offered to let the dog out to join us in the backyard 
on the kitten's first experimental walk outside, telling my dad to go 
ahead. Big golden comes racing up, kitten freaks like a demon is after him, 
and only me grabbing him quickly kept him from escaping me as he escaped 
his harness. The harness is as small as it can go, and the kitten size one 
is too small for him, so my mom's fears aren't unreasonable. What should I 
do?
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
+kukui buss
I'm glad you are starting the training with a kitten! At the same time I 
was doing the leash training, I was also doing door etiquette with the 
cats. Just as Cesar Millan trains dogs, I train my cats to respect the 
entryway space. I can open my door wide, and the cats will not dash out. 
This training does not stick permanently, and you have to refresh them from 
time to time, but it's workable.

So, train them on door manners as well as leash manners, and your life will 
be easier. Also, your mom doesn't want to hold her sobbing daughter? That's 
just cold. :P
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text:
+RedTLT +Sun Dog I was wondering... another reason my mom doesn't want me 
taking the kitten on walks is because she doesn't want to be holding a 
sobbing daughter when the kitten gets loose or gets out. What arguments can 
I make?
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
+RedTLT
This is accurate! I have leash cats too, and they don't try to get out as 
much as other cats I had that were not taken out on leash for walkies.
comments.author: Sun Dog

comments.text:
Thanks! I'll show your post to my mom, but I still hope Jackson will 
contact me back.
comments.author: kukui buss

comments.text:
I have a cat that is harness trained (likes to go out), cats are pretty 
smart mine knows that if he wants to go outside he can only go on his 
harness...I am currently training another cat to do the same....it doesn't 
really take them long to know that to go out they must be on a leash...as 
soon as I take the harnesses out they KNOW it's outside time...being 
outside is a treat to them and they learn pretty quickly!  Just try it you 
and your cat will love this!
comments.author: RedTLT

comments.text:
I have the same question. I'd like to take my cats out on a harness but how 
do I make sure they know the only time that it is okay to go outside is 
when they have the harness on and I'm with them?
comments.author: LadyandHerCrazyCats

captions.text: Team Cat Mojo-- I am excited.
Can you tell?

I've been waiting
to put this down

into the video ether
for quite a long time.
Now I get the chance.
Can't wait, man

We are going to be talking
today about the confident where.
Are you ready to get catified?
Let's go.

So what we're really
talking about today
is the confident where.

Where in the world
are they confident?

Is your cat a bush
dweller, a tree dweller,
or a beach dweller?

A bush dweller is a type
of cat who is always

hiding under the coffee
table, or they're
behind a potted plant, a bush.
And they are waiting to do what?

In the raw cat mind, if we
think about cats in the wild,
what are they waiting to do?

They're waiting to hunt, to
strike, to get your ankles,
to do something.

They're down there
getting their mojo on.

Now, tree dweller,
pretty obvious--

if they're not down
there on the floor

behind the potted plant,
what are they doing?
They're up there, somewhere.

Now, here's the important
thing with tree dwellers.

It can be anywhere
above the ground.

Tree dwelling
doesn't necessarily
mean way up in the rafters.
Rafters included, for sure.
But it can be this chair.
It can be this table.
It can be on top of the couch.
It can be way up in the rafters.

But they are demonstrating
confidence up.

The beach dweller still
lives out on the floor,

likes to feel all four paws are
firmly touching terra firma.
Got it.
However, they do like being out.

Yes, you know that
cat, the cat that you

trip over, every day, when
you come into the living room.

And you haven't had
your coffee yet.

And you go face planting
into the kitchen,

because you've tripped
on your beach cat.

What they're doing is, they're
sending a clear message

to you and to the other
animals in the house.

Basically, if you want to
get from point A to point B,

you're going to have to not
take the straightest path.

You're going to have
to go around me.

Remember something, it's
all about Cat Mojo 101.
Which is what?

Confident ownership
of territory-- where

does your cat
demonstrate confidence?

Well, what's the
anti-confident where?

Where are the places
where your cat develops
a lack of confidence, fear.

Now, if you use the
word hide, then you're
not talking about a dweller.
You're talking about a hider.
You're talking about a caver.

So if a cat is
caving, that's saying

that they like to
be small, invisible.

If they could, they would
disappear into their cave.
That's what makes a cat a caver.

So what turns a caved
cat into a bush dweller?

Well, I'm glad you
asked, because this

is what catification
is all about.

Catification is getting
you to the point, where

instead of hiding, where we
can't find you-- oh, you're

behind that shoe box
back there-- to creating

an environment where
it's under our control,

where we're saying,
you know what.

It's OK if you want to be
in an enclosed environment.

But we want it to be
where we want it to be.
Let's look at another example.

You say, Jackson Galaxy, I have
a cat who's a tree dweller.
He never comes off the fridge.
Huh?
What?

No, you're cat is not
confident on top of the fridge.
Your cat is fridging.

They're up there
trying to get away

from other cats
who are tormenting
them or kids or humans.

They're not coming down, because
they only feel safe there.
They can disappear up there.

Safety does not
equal confidence.
It's a component of.

But that's the pendulum
swinging way to the other side.

We want your cat to
be the mojito cat.

We want your cat up like that
and ready to take on the world.

And if they're on top of
the fridge, that ain't it.
So what are we trying to do?

We're trying to
transition the fridge cat
to be a tree dweller.
And how do we do that?
We catify.

We give the world ramps
and a cat superhighway,

to make sure they can move
around there with confidence.

And then over time,
we encourage them

to come down and join
the rest of the world.

So what our job is-- if our cat
is displaying the unconfident

where, if our cat is
displaying fear and the urge

to disappear and be small,
we want to say to them,

just as if they were our
children, go out there.
Step into your greatness.

And the way a cat steps
into their greatness
is territorially.

If they only own the joint,
they are a confident genius
of a cat.
And that's what we want.

We don't want to
change our cats.

We don't want them to
be someone they're not.

If they're introspective,
that's who they are.

If they're life of the
party, that's who they are.

But we don't want
the introverted cat
to become a hermit.
That's not a good life.
You know your cat.

And if you don't know
your cat, all you've
gotta do is watch them.

All you've gotta do is
put on your cat glasses
and watch them.

And you will find out the
most intense stuff, man.

Hey, what makes
us Team Cat Mojo?
It's the we.
It's the us.

And how do we become
a we and an us?

And how do we make life
better for cats, our cats,

all those cats, shelter
cats, cats on the street?
We spread the word.
We talk to one another.
We become a community.
So how do you do that?

Subscribe-- leave
me a comment here,

so that I talk about the
things you want to hear about.

And find me on Twitter and
on Facebook and on Instagram
and Google+.

And speaking of
Google Hangouts, be

sure to join me on
Wednesday, February 5.
I'll answer your questions.

And we're going to talk
more about declawing.

So stay tuned for
more information,

but man, get that on your
calendar and do it now.

You have been watching "Cat
Mojo" with Jackson Galaxy.
Please stay tuned.
There is so much more to come.

And until we talk again, folks,
light, love, and mojo to you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Help Your Cat with "The Confident Where"
